clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of tDCS on Motor Learning and Neural Network in Stroke Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Investigation of Compensational Mechanism and Effect of Transcranial Direct Stimulation on Motor Learning Through Neural Network Analysis in Stroke Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This study is to investigate the effect of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) simulation on motor learning to stroke patients compared to sham stimulation

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
primary_outcome.description: The score is a stroke-specific, performance-based impairment index. The degree of impairment of upper and lower limbs is measured.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in cortical activity using fNIRS signals during brain stimulation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, during, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: Cortical activities before, during and after brain stimulation sessions are compared.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: Resting motor threshold (rMT) and amplitude of motor evoked potential in first dorsal interosseous muscle are measured. These outcomes are measured by transcranial magnetic stimulation over the motor hotspot. The rMT is defined as the minimum stimulus intensity that produced a minimal motor evoked response at rest. The amplitude means peak to peak of the muscle response.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: The test is a standardized, quantitative assessment used to measure finger dexterity of a patient.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: The test is to measure the maximum isometric strength of hand, forearm, and finger muscles.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: The test is used to measure the gross manual dexterity of a patient, or of a person using an upper limb prosthetic device.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: Response time is measured during sequential finger tapping task.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions
secondary_outcome.description: This test is a standardized and objective measure of fine and gross motor hand function using simulated activities of daily living (ADL).

other_outcome.description: Before intervention, MRI is acquired to extract brain characteristics of stroke patients.

other_outcome.measure: Changes in cortical activity using fNIRS signals.
other_outcome.description: Before intervention, fNIRS image is acquired to extract cortical activation of stroke patients.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Real stimulation before motor learning training
arm_group.description: Patients receive five sessions of tDCS stimulation over C3 (patient with left-sided lesion) or C4 (patient with right-sided lesion) based on 10-20 system immediately before sequential finger tapping task.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Sham stimulation before motor learning training
arm_group.description: Patients receive five sessions of sham stimulation over C3 (patient with left-sided lesion) or C4 (patient with right-sided lesion) based on 10-20 system immediately before sequential finger tapping task.

intervention.description: Transcranial direct current stimulation is a form of noninvasive neuromodulation that uses constant and low direct current delivered via electrodes on the scalp.
intervention.arm_group_label: Real stimulation before motor learning training

intervention.description: Sequential finger tapping task training is applied to stroke patients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Unilateral stroke including basal ganglia lesion patients
- Chronic patients over 6 months after onset
- Patients with the movement of fingers
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of psychiatric disease
- Significant other neurological diseases except for stroke
- Difficult to perform this experiment
- Patients who are deemed difficult to participate in this research by the investigator
- Patients with metal implants and medical devices
- History of epilepsy
- Pregnancy
- Skin defect at the site of electrode attachment
